discourse_list.title: Justin Sun borrowed 24k MKR from Aave

content.content: So Justin Sun suspiciously borrowed 24k MKR from Aave Possible outcome, he will dump it and buy back cheaper and repay the 24k MKR. He and other market participants have colluded to force a shutdown before the threshold is raised to 100k, this is less likely because he borrowed originally 40k  and paid back 16k after that, it’s disconcerting that he can borrow 40k on his own. I feel that new 100k MKR threshold for the Emergency Shutdown Module is also to low. Those are my thoughts, maybe you have a more reasonable explanation.  image1363×236 18.2 KB
My guess is he will vote on Community Greenlight Poll - TUSD-PSM (TrueUSD).
pretty sure it is about the TUSD-PSM - watch the poll carefully  image964×553 71 KB  abstain is not a good option imho @MakerMan @monet-supply
Switched to NO but 24K will still put this over. @flipflopflapdelegate who himself could push this one way or another sitting this poll out? And back to @monet-supply to make a decision here.
MakerMan:  @ElProgreso who himself could push this one way or another sitting this poll out?   3F Delegate never sits out an election
He has shown that he can easily borrow more to override the general consensus, an interesting development
so either  we win this poll now MKR holders will realize that not participating in governance / not delegating is bad  ?

I agree with you, but the incentives are very low, or rather they are very general so that individuals can hardly identify with them, but these are well-known problems like not participate or do not delegate, tokenomics, etc lack of marketing communication and the incentive that you get something good with it is better than spreading fear for something is going to get worse.
It was experimental  (MKR returned to AAVE): https://etherscan.io/tx/0x6af5464a00112c0e72b35a45c1fd2172f7ce193ba82b21cd4e35282df4a74417

We should thank him for clearly demonstrating the risks of having a low amount of MKR on the hat/and or MKR holders depositing into lending platforms. This obviously isn’t anything new, it’s a well documented risk known to the community, but hopefully some MKR whales are paying attention this time around.

I’m glad that he returned the MKR, but it’s a major red flag that we needed our delegates to scramble around to prevent a voting whale. I hope that @0xdeniz and @Andrew_Hall can include in their governance research how to address these governance attacks situations so that a few whales don’t determine the fate of the protocol. Some top-of-mind thoughts are reevaluating MKR borrowing, implementing time locks, and generally increasing education/awareness or promoting vote notifications with EPNS. In addition to encouraging more participation, maybe we need more delegates for better representation
I suppose he has done us a favor by showing this governance weakness. Should Maker consider time requirements before MKR holders can vote, so only longer term committed folks can vote?

I would not set even more boundaries for participation, people are lending MKR because they can use it as a collateral ether to borrow stable coins or other assets, I was thinking of a possible GMKR token, you will receive for delegate or to have it in the governance smart contract, with the GMKR you can generate Dai with attractive rates. So you would increase the participation in the governance, I think more MKR would be in the Governance participation, also increase demand for MKR general.

Good comments (also by @lollike)  I’ll chime in by sharing that today’s events have inspired us DUX to come up with a new feature idea for the Governance Portal, which should help bring awareness/visibility to situations that might pose a danger to Maker governance. We’ll share initial thoughts/teasers soon
Plus one to time locks and more delegates.

twblack88:  Plus one to time locks and more delegates.   Yeah I think there is consensus to this. Or something similar. @rune in his Sagittarium Engine proposal, suggested to increase the voting weight of people locking for a long time (beside other benefits). This is very much needed. Somebody proposed in the Maker chat to talk to Aave/Compound to limit the MKR-borrowing options. But I seriously doubt this type of approach will work (medium/long term) in DeFi, which is an open environment. What we need are better tokenomics/incentives, for MKR holders to do the right thing.
